body:
Can you share an example? Works fine for me on Google Drive and Dropbox:

```
felix@gemini:~/test$ touch -a -m -t 196901181205.09 blah
felix@gemini:~/test$ ls -al
total 8
drwxrwxr-x  2 felix felix 4096 Jan 14 15:27 .
drwxr-xr-x 17 felix felix 4096 Jan 14 08:17 ..
-rw-rw-r--  1 felix felix    0 Jan 18  1969 blah
felix@gemini:~/test$ stat blah
  File: blah
  Size: 0         	Blocks: 0          IO Block: 4096   regular empty file
Device: 802h/2050d	Inode: 42336951    Links: 1
Access: (0664/-rw-rw-r--)  Uid: ( 1000/   felix)   Gid: ( 1000/   felix)
Access: 1969-01-18 12:05:09.000000000 -0500
Modify: 1969-01-18 12:05:09.000000000 -0500
Change: 2022-01-14 15:28:52.043648719 -0500
 Birth: -
felix@gemini:~/test$
felix@gemini:~/test$
felix@gemini:~/test$ rclone copy blah GD: -vvv
2022/01/14 15:29:06 DEBUG : Setting --config "/opt/rclone/rclone.conf" from environment variable RCLONE_CONFIG="/opt/rclone/rclone.conf"
2022/01/14 15:29:06 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.57.0" starting with parameters ["rclone" "copy" "blah" "GD:" "-vvv"]
2022/01/14 15:29:06 DEBUG : Creating backend with remote "blah"
2022/01/14 15:29:06 DEBUG : Using config file from "/opt/rclone/rclone.conf"
2022/01/14 15:29:06 DEBUG : fs cache: adding new entry for parent of "blah", "/home/felix/test"
2022/01/14 15:29:06 DEBUG : Creating backend with remote "GD:"
2022/01/14 15:29:06 DEBUG : GD: Loaded invalid token from config file - ignoring
2022/01/14 15:29:06 DEBUG : Saving config "token" in section "GD" of the config file
2022/01/14 15:29:06 DEBUG : GD: Saved new token in config file
2022/01/14 15:29:07 DEBUG : blah: Need to transfer - File not found at Destination
2022/01/14 15:29:08 DEBUG : blah: md5 = d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e OK
2022/01/14 15:29:08 INFO  : blah: Copied (new)
2022/01/14 15:29:08 INFO  :
Transferred:   	          0 B / 0 B, -, 0 B/s, ETA -
Transferred:            1 / 1, 100%
Elapsed time:         1.5s

2022/01/14 15:29:08 DEBUG : 7 go routines active
felix@gemini:~/test$ rclone lsl blah
        0 1969-01-18 12:05:09.000000000 blah
felix@gemini:~/test$ rclone copy blah DB: -vvv
2022/01/14 15:29:30 DEBUG : Setting --config "/opt/rclone/rclone.conf" from environment variable RCLONE_CONFIG="/opt/rclone/rclone.conf"
2022/01/14 15:29:30 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.57.0" starting with parameters ["rclone" "copy" "blah" "DB:" "-vvv"]
2022/01/14 15:29:30 DEBUG : Creating backend with remote "blah"
2022/01/14 15:29:30 DEBUG : Using config file from "/opt/rclone/rclone.conf"
2022/01/14 15:29:30 DEBUG : fs cache: adding new entry for parent of "blah", "/home/felix/test"
2022/01/14 15:29:30 DEBUG : Creating backend with remote "DB:"
2022/01/14 15:29:31 DEBUG : blah: Need to transfer - File not found at Destination
2022/01/14 15:29:31 DEBUG : blah: Uploading chunk 1/0
2022/01/14 15:29:31 DEBUG : blah: Uploading chunk 2/0
2022/01/14 15:29:32 DEBUG : Dropbox root '': Adding "/blah" to batch
2022/01/14 15:29:32 DEBUG : Dropbox root '': Batch idle for 500ms so committing
2022/01/14 15:29:32 DEBUG : Dropbox root '': Committing sync batch length 1 starting with: /blah
2022/01/14 15:29:33 DEBUG : Dropbox root '': Upload batch completed in 171.511103ms
2022/01/14 15:29:33 DEBUG : Dropbox root '': Committed sync batch length 1 starting with: /blah
2022/01/14 15:29:33 DEBUG : blah: dropbox = e3b0c44298fc1c149afbf4c8996fb92427ae41e4649b934ca495991b7852b855 OK
2022/01/14 15:29:33 INFO  : blah: Copied (new)
2022/01/14 15:29:33 INFO  :
Transferred:   	          0 B / 0 B, -, 0 B/s, ETA -
Transferred:            1 / 1, 100%
Elapsed time:         2.8s

2022/01/14 15:29:33 DEBUG : 9 go routines active
2022/01/14 15:29:33 INFO  : Dropbox root '': Commiting uploads - please wait...
felix@gemini:~/test$ rclone lsl DB:blah
        0 1969-01-18 12:05:09.000000000 blah
```
And times before epoch in Unix/Linux are just negative seconds so that's a normal thing.

If you pick one file run it through with --dump requests with debug, that should show the value as well.

DB spits out something like:

```
{"entries":[{"cursor":{"session_id":"pid_upload_session:ABIEcoyvIaetXbrGUlUjbl5i7bjNT5UX3M7y9TAA0QT0kV87","offset":0},"commit":{"path":"/blah","mode":{".tag":"overwrite"},"autorename":false,"client_modified":"1969-01-18T17:05:09Z","mute":false,"strict_conflict":false}}]}
```

I've got two example photos:

The file 564055883.115027.jpg locally has a last-modified date of 4/1/1969, 11:11
After the rclone sync, the file's timestamp on pCloud changes to 1/13/2022, 10:05.

The file 564058497.078798.jpg locally has a last-modified date of 7/1/1980, 11:54
After the rclone sync, the file's timestamp on pCloud stays at  7/1/1980, 11:54.

If I copy the same files using the pCloud Sync application (on macOS), both files keep their original timestamp also on pCloud, so obviously, the backend can handle it. 

Is that the example you require?

Can you follow my example and produce the same output for one photo?

Steps:

1) Find one "bad" photo
2) rclone copy that one photo to a fresh spot on your pcloud with -vvv on the command and share the full output
3) delete photo from pcloud on step 2 and re-run the same thing with --dump requests and share the full output

```
rclone copy 564055883.115027.jpg pCloud:AWS -vvv
2022/01/17 16:04:27 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.57.0" starting with parameters ["rclone" "copy" "564055883.115027.jpg" "pCloud:AWS" "-vvv"]
2022/01/17 16:04:27 DEBUG : Creating backend with remote "564055883.115027.jpg"
2022/01/17 16:04:27 DEBUG : Using config file from "/var/services/homes/xxxx/.config/rclone/rclone.conf"
2022/01/17 16:04:27 DEBUG : fs cache: adding new entry for parent of "564055883.115027.jpg", "/volume2/photo/xxxx"
2022/01/17 16:04:27 DEBUG : Creating backend with remote "pCloud:AWS"
2022/01/17 16:04:28 DEBUG : 564055883.115027.jpg: Need to transfer - File not found at Destination
2022/01/17 16:05:02 DEBUG : 564055883.115027.jpg: sha1 = d1cd0d4e1cb90e4b44f39bd290d00612c35da41e OK
2022/01/17 16:05:02 INFO  : 564055883.115027.jpg: Copied (new)
2022/01/17 16:05:02 INFO  : 
Transferred:   	  841.176 KiB / 841.176 KiB, 100%, 21.647 KiB/s, ETA 0s
Transferred:            1 / 1, 100%
Elapsed time:        35.3s

2022/01/17 16:05:02 DEBUG : 5 go routines active
```

and the result is 

```
rclone lsjson pCloud:AWS
[
{"Path":"564055883.115027.jpg","Name":"564055883.115027.jpg","Size":861364,"MimeType":"image/jpeg","ModTime":"2022-01-17T15:05:01Z","IsDir":false,"ID":"f9711420264"}
]
```

The dump requests is the good one.

You can use three backtics -> `

```
before and after a section
```

To make a code block.

```
2022/01/17 17:23:33 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.57.0" starting with parameters ["rclone" "copy" "564
055883.115027.jpg" "pCloud:AWS" "-vvv" "--dump" "requests"]

ill be gunzipped before showing it.

```

Result
```
[
{"Path":"564055883.115027.jpg","Name":"564055883.115027.jpg","Size":861364,"MimeType":"image/jpeg","ModTime":"2022-01-17T16:24:05Z","IsDir":false,"ID":"f9711420264"}
]
```

So to my eye, that looks like the request is proper:

```
2022/01/17 17:23:33 DEBUG : PUT /uploadfile?filename=564055883.115027.jpg&folderid=2077653918&mtime=
-23723317&nopartial=1 HTTP/1.1
```

The mtime is a negative number and goes back to what you'd expect:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5088712/149808314-801a3aea-61ab-43ac-b70d-a057b34507da.png)


So I'd imagine that's a pcloud API bug and not rclone related.

I'm not sure if @ivandeex or @ncw can confirm what I'm seeing and how they normally handle those things but I feel we got all the needed info at this point.

Right, the request seems to be correct. The API docs of pCloud are not clear about whether negative values are allowed here or not:
```
mtime | int if set, file modified time is set. Have to be unix time seconds.
ctime | int if set, file created time is set. It's required to provide mtime to set ctime. Have to be unix time seconds.
``` 
However the fact, that the pCloud software can do it correctly, seems to imply that they are using another API or another data type or whatever.

I wouldn't venture to guess how a vendor's app compares to their published API or what they use or don't use internally we only have access to the published API and the docs and rclone seems to be doing everything correct.

Next steps would be just to wait for a response from the folks I tagged and see how they want to proceed.

There are two pCloud APIs a JSON one an a binary one.  Rclone uses the JSON API maybe the Native App uses the binary one?

I think this is probably a bug in the pCloud JSON API not accepting negative numbers for the mtime. Its possible that if rclone sent the number as an unsigned 64 bit number it would work (that would make sense if it works with the binary API)...

I tried this and it worked in my testing so can you give it a go?

[v1.58.0-beta.5935.48d55d6fa.fix-5917-pcloud-mtime](https://beta.rclone.org/branch/fix-5917-pcloud-mtime/v1.58.0-beta.5935.48d55d6fa.fix-5917-pcloud-mtime/) on branch [fix-5917-pcloud-mtime](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/tree/fix-5917-pcloud-mtime) (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

This sends the negative timestamps as a very large positive number 18446744073678057256 which interpreted as a signed 64 bit number is -31494360. This seems to workaround the bug!
I've merged this to master now which means it will be in [the latest beta](https://beta.rclone.org/) in 15-30 minutes and released in v1.58

Hi, I don't know that should I open a new issue for that, but I experience similar issue but between two local ntfs-3g path.

like from modification date on source 1665.12.01. it changes to 2250.06.22. on destionation files.
That means every time I run a dry-run or live copy, it recognise the difference and trying to modify dates....

I tested with midnight commander, rsync. Both transfers date like 1665.12.01. flawlessly between those 2 path.

@Smyl3 that sounds like a different issue. How are you accessing your ntfs-3g files - via FUSE on linux? Can you make a new issue and put full details in, including how to replicate the problem - thanks

issue.title: Old Last modified date not preserved/changed between copy of two ntfs-3g path/device

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?

When using rclone copy between two ntfs-3g path/device, very old dates changes to a future date which shows difference between the 2 files every time it runs.

Like from file modification date on source 1665.12.01. it changes to 2250.06.22. on destination files.
That means every time I run a dry-run or live copy, it recognise the difference and trying to modify dates again but it fails....

I tested with midnight commander, rsync. Both transfers date like 1665.12.01. flawlessly between those 2 path.


For reference, related similar issue that I found and where I asked about it: 
https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/5917


#### What is your rclone version (output from `rclone version`)
```
❯ rclone version
rclone v1.71.0
- os/version: cachyos (64 bit)
- os/kernel: 6.16.4-4-cachyos (x86_64)
- os/type: linux
- os/arch: amd64
- go/version: go1.24.6
- go/linking: dynamic
- go/tags: none
```

```
❯ mount
/dev/sdd1 on /mnt/usb/wd-feher/backup type fuseblk (rw,nosuid,nodev,noatime,user_id=0,group_id=0,default_permissions,allow_other,blksize=4096)
/dev/sda2 on /mnt/ntfs-fix/k type fuseblk (rw,nosuid,nodev,noatime,user_id=0,group_id=0,default_permissions,allow_other,blksize=4096,x-gvfs-show)
```

#### Which OS you are using and how many bits (e.g. Windows 7, 64 bit)
```
❯ uname -a
Linux cachyos-x8664 6.16.4-4-cachyos #1 SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Wed, 03 Sep 2025 14:45:16 +0000 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

#### Which cloud storage system are you using? (e.g. Google Drive)

ntfs-3g source and target drive

#### The command you were trying to run (e.g. `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

rclone copy '/mnt/ntfs-fix/k/rclone-test/' '/mnt/usb/wd-feher/backup/teeszt/'   --links --modify-window=1s -vv

#### A log from the command with the `-vv` flag (e.g. output from `rclone -vv copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

```
~/scripts/backup

2025/09/17 22:57:10 DEBUG : Creating backend with remote "/mnt/ntfs-fix/k/rclone-test/"
```

#### How to use GitHub

* Please use the 👍 [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to show that you are affected by the same issue.
* Please don't comment if you have no relevant information to add. It's just extra noise for everyone subscribed to this issue.
* Subscribe to receive notifications on status change and new comments.
